description:
The Gilbert has been developed as an all
encompassing work and social space. The building celebrates it's original 20th Century construction, whilst creating a uniquely modern building with a focus on sustainable architecture.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Although focused on the working lifestyles of the present day, the building has a story to tell. Originally designed as a private members club by Frederick Gould and Giles Gilbert Scott, designer of the iconic British red telephone box and architect of Bankside Power Station now the Tate Modern, The Gilbert has been returned to its former glory.

Close attention has been paid to the unique and original features of this magnificent heritage building. The Gilbert brings out the distinctive, characterful – surprising – nature of the original building, and introduces new standards of daylight, exterior spaces and clean air via natural ventilation from opening windows and sustainability.

factsheet.heading: Sustainability
paragraphs: The Gilbert is the first Brookfield Properties building completed as Net Zero in Construction. The development intervention has extended the lifecycle of the existing building and made it more relevant for the current and future needs of a workspace, while retaining original architectural features.

Headline Features
- 90% of the original structure was retained 
- Embodied CO2 was 147.1kg CO2/m2  VS 600 kg CO2/m2 LETI Benchmark (19.6%)
- 9,500 tonnes less Embodied Carbon than LETI Benchmark

How this was achieved: 
1. Embodied Carbon: The retention of 90% of the original structure resulted in major carbon savings- 9,500 tonnes less than LETI Office Benchmark. 
2. Operational Energy: The Gilbert’s energy saving measures resulted in an estimated consumption of 87.3 kWhe/m2.- 3% lower than the UKGBC benchmark for Net Zero Carbon pathway.
3. Offsetting: Once due diligence was complete to account for all possible avenues for reduction of embodied carbon, 3100 tonnes of residual carbon emissions were offset with the purchase of the Fresh Breeze Project in Mexico.
The renovation of The Gilbert created less than 20% of the embedded CO2 emissions compared to a new building and achieves a comparable energy efficiency.

The impact of choosing office space in the Gilbert corresponds to avoiding immediately around 9,000 kgCO2e* per workplace. That’s equivalent to stopping using your car for 4.5 years, avoiding flying from London to New York 29 times or planting 450 trees!

factsheet.heading: Green Space
paragraphs: The building offers one 3,121 sq ft courtyard and 6 terraces totalling 7,287 sq ft.

name: The Gilbert
